item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Lin:

floor(log(abs(x))) + 1

[s]
x = 10
floor(log(abs(10))) + 1
floor(log(10)) + 1
floor(2) + 1
2 + 1
3

I realised this while writing mine, hence the “exact? y” condition in my function.
[/s]

shhhhh, i am tireddddd

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:477306”]The string solution is, imo, the best.

Taharoks is overly simple, doesn’t consider negatives or 0.

The log approach is kinda fine, but probably just as slow as the string manipulation anyway, and way less clear. It makes sense to convert to a string and do string manip, because the number of digits is a string property - integers do not have a ‘length’, string representations of integers do.[/quote]

Your String-based solution is perfectly OK, there is nothing "un-neat" about it. You have to realize that mathematically, numbers don't have a length, nor do they have digits. Length and digits are both properties of a physical representation of a number in a specific base, i.e. a String.

A logarithm-based solution does (some of) the same things the String-based one does internally, and probably does so (insignificantly) faster because it only produces the length and ignores the digits. But I wouldn’t actually consider it clearer in intent - and that’s the most important factor.


I agree with you though. I wrote it before looking it up anyway because it seemed the most obvious.

Read full topic

item.description:

Taharoks is overly simple, doesn’t consider negatives or 0.

The log approach is kinda fine, but probably just as slow as the string manipulation anyway, and way less clear. It makes sense to convert to a string and do string manip, because the number of digits is a string property - integers do not have a ‘length’, string representations of integers do.[/quote]

Division works on negatives. The only thing that needs to be considered is zero, which can be done with a simple conditional.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I’m well familiar with the language. I’ve been using it for 6 years. I’m not alone in my opinions, but they are just from a humble professional web developer. I use the language more than I’d like, which is where my dislike for it has come from. I would not discourage anyone from using it and I would likely implement it in various other applications myself. Nevertheless, I still find it flawed, just as much as I find any other language I use flawed.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:15, topic:477306”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=595500.msg4193119#msg4193119 date=1357099170]
Comparing it to other scripting/interpreted languages, it’s fast. Obviously it doesn’t need to be fast and that may not have been an initial design goal, but it’s only getting faster. I’d also like to know what you consider to be badly designed.

And when I was saying comparing those methods, obviously the one with the internal method is going to be faster.

There are profilers you can use as well to see what’s going on in your programs.
[/quote]

Right, but how do you compare its “speed” to that of another scripting language? What basis are your benchmarks in claiming Javascript is faster? That’s a completely arbitrary thing to say, because it’s down to the implementation of the language to determine its speed, not the language itself.

I think that the convoluted and often confusing nature of objects versus arrays in Javascript is poorly designed. If you compare the types of two separate, buy valid, expressions for creating an array, one will be of the type array and the other of type object (ie, using [] versus new Array). Another really complex feature of Javascript is its shared scopes between function calls. I would blindly say that anyone who’s used Javascript enough will have experienced this feature and, unless you already knew about it, you probably were frustrated by almost undefined behavior because of how weird the results can be when variables are changeable across multiple function calls.

There’s more to complain about, but this topic is not for finding the flaws of Javascript, it’s for finding neat ways of counting the number of digits in an integer.[/quote]
The tests for determining its speed weren’t done by me, they were common tasks done in different scripting languages by different people. You can find a lot of benchmarks published online.

To explain that array behaviour, arrays are objects in Javascript. Almost everything in Javascript is an object (besides null). Doing:

var x = new Array();
typeof x; // 'object'
var q = [];
typeof q; // 'object'

So not sure what you mean when you say that they’re different types.

I have no idea what you mean about shared scope between functions. You might be referring to the fact that Javascript doesn’t have block scope using var and that can cause issues if you don’t know Javascript, but that’s why you should learn a language before using it.

Obviously the language isn’t perfect, it has a few minor flaws, but I wouldn’t say anything is wrong with the overall design of the language.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:14, topic:477306”]Comparing it to other scripting/interpreted languages, it’s fast. Obviously it doesn’t need to be fast and that may not have been an initial design goal, but it’s only getting faster. I’d also like to know what you consider to be badly designed.

And when I was saying comparing those methods, obviously the one with the internal method is going to be faster.

There are profilers you can use as well to see what’s going on in your programs.[/quote]

Right, but how do you compare its “speed” to that of another scripting language? What basis are your benchmarks in claiming Javascript is faster? That’s a completely arbitrary thing to say, because it’s down to the implementation of the language to determine its speed, not the language itself.

I think that the convoluted and often confusing nature of objects versus arrays in Javascript is poorly designed. If you compare the types of two separate, buy valid, expressions for creating an array, one will be of the type array and the other of type object (ie, using [] versus new Array). Another really complex feature of Javascript is its shared scopes between function calls. I would blindly say that anyone who’s used Javascript enough will have experienced this feature and, unless you already knew about it, you probably were frustrated by almost undefined behavior because of how weird the results can be when variables are changeable across multiple function calls.

There’s more to complain about, but this topic is not for finding the flaws of Javascript, it’s for finding neat ways of counting the number of digits in an integer.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:13, topic:477306”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=595500.msg4192955#msg4192955 date=1357082768]

[quote author=Taharok link=topic=595500.msg4192931#msg4192931 date=1357081113]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=595500.msg4192920#msg4192920 date=1357080827]

You’re counting the negative sign there

Obviously that does work, but you have to remember that toString() is an expensive operation. I’m thinking of more imaginative ways!
[/quote]No I’m not! And it isn’t that expensive in this case.

EDIT: I did some tests and it’s a lot faster than Taharok’s more imaginative method (in JavaScript at least).

That’s because JavaScript is interpreted. The toString method will be executed internally and not through interpretation (at least, I would imagine, though this depends on the implementation). My way should be significantly faster in a lower-level language.
[/quote]Oh yeah I’m not knocking your method, I’m just saying you don’t get the speed benefits of writing code like that in Javascript.

I agree with you. You shouldn’t be looking for speed benefits like this in JavaScript, anyway. It’s a slow language to begin with, so you shouldn’t be worrying about microoptimizations in it.
[/quote]JavaScript is obviously a slow language compared to statically-typed compiled languages, but for an interpreted language, it’s usually pretty fast (depending on the implementation).

JavaScript is not a very fast language and, beyond that, it’s also poorly designed. It’s incredibly useful and easy to pick up. Yet, for all its worth, few people seem to actually really know it or use it per-spec or properly. It’s not meant to be fast, it’s meant to be convenient. For that, it is.[/quote]Comparing it to other scripting/interpreted languages, it’s fast. Obviously it doesn’t need to be fast and that may not have been an initial design goal, but it’s only getting faster. I’d also like to know what you consider to be badly designed.

And when I was saying comparing those methods, obviously the one with the internal method is going to be faster.

There are profilers you can use as well to see what’s going on in your programs.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:12, topic:477306”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=595500.msg4192931#msg4192931 date=1357081113]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=595500.msg4192920#msg4192920 date=1357080827]

[quote author=Taharok link=topic=595500.msg4192918#msg4192918 date=1357080406]

You’re counting the negative sign there

Obviously that does work, but you have to remember that toString() is an expensive operation. I’m thinking of more imaginative ways!
[/quote]No I’m not! And it isn’t that expensive in this case.

EDIT: I did some tests and it’s a lot faster than Taharok’s more imaginative method (in JavaScript at least).

That’s because JavaScript is interpreted. The toString method will be executed internally and not through interpretation (at least, I would imagine, though this depends on the implementation). My way should be significantly faster in a lower-level language.
[/quote]Oh yeah I’m not knocking your method, I’m just saying you don’t get the speed benefits of writing code like that in Javascript.

I agree with you. You shouldn’t be looking for speed benefits like this in JavaScript, anyway. It’s a slow language to begin with, so you shouldn’t be worrying about microoptimizations in it.
[/quote]JavaScript is obviously a slow language compared to statically-typed compiled languages, but for an interpreted language, it’s usually pretty fast (depending on the implementation).[/quote]

Well, what do you consider fast? How are you even able to do a benchmark of these algorithms in Javascript? You would need to test both of these procedures side-by-side across multiple implementations. Even then, you are comparing an internal feature with an external algorithm. It would be fairer to write your own version of converting a number to a string, then counting its length. I guarantee it will be slower.

Beyond that, the language cannot be relied upon for speed comparisons. How do you know what the underlying implementation is doing at any given time? Perhaps it is using a hotspot compiler arbitrarily through the middle of one of the executions, significantly slowing down runtime before it gets very fast. There’s no way to know.

JavaScript is not a very fast language and, beyond that, it’s also poorly designed. It’s incredibly useful and easy to pick up. Yet, for all its worth, few people seem to actually really know it or use it per-spec or properly. It’s not meant to be fast, it’s meant to be convenient. For that, it is.

Read full topic

item.title: Count_digits
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:10, topic:477306”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=595500.msg4192920#msg4192920 date=1357080827]

[quote author=Taharok link=topic=595500.msg4192918#msg4192918 date=1357080406]

You’re counting the negative sign there

Obviously that does work, but you have to remember that toString() is an expensive operation. I’m thinking of more imaginative ways!
[/quote]No I’m not! And it isn’t that expensive in this case.

EDIT: I did some tests and it’s a lot faster than Taharok’s more imaginative method (in JavaScript at least).

That’s because JavaScript is interpreted. The toString method will be executed internally and not through interpretation (at least, I would imagine, though this depends on the implementation). My way should be significantly faster in a lower-level language.
[/quote]Oh yeah I’m not knocking your method, I’m just saying you don’t get the speed benefits of writing code like that in Javascript.

I agree with you. You shouldn’t be looking for speed benefits like this in JavaScript, anyway. It’s a slow language to begin with, so you shouldn’t be worrying about microoptimizations in it.[/quote]JavaScript is obviously a slow language compared to statically-typed compiled languages, but for an interpreted language, it’s usually pretty fast (depending on the implementation).

Read full topic
